Herein, the word Praja is significant.
The etymological import of the word is that which is born, Praja, that which is born.
On the earth, there are many species of life from aquatics up to the perfect human beings

Praja doesn't mean only human beings.
Praja means all living beings who take birth in this world.

Which includes the partial service to the living beings who form the parts and parcels of the complete whole.
So when Yudhishthira Maharaj is serving the Supreme Lord Krishna,
that means he is also engaged in serving the living beings who are part of Krishna.
Those who are busy rendering service to the parts and parcels, leaving aside the whole,
only spoil time and energy as one does when watering the leaves of a tree without watering the root.
This is the example given in the Bhagavatam.
As when watering the root of a very big tree,
all the branches, the leaves, the twigs, every other part of the tree
is completely nourished by the watering of the root of the tree.
Exactly like that.
When one renders service to Krishna who is the complete whole,
then all the parts and parcels, the living entities,
they are automatically served.
By this one action of serving Krishna.
If water is poured on the root of the tree,
the leaves are enlivened perfectly and automatically.
But if water is poured on the leaves only, the whole energy is spoiled.
Maharaj Yudhishthira therefore was constantly engaged in the service of the Lord
and thus the parts and parcels of the Lord, the living beings,
under his careful administration,
were perfectly attended with all comforts in this life
and all progress in the next.
That is the way of perfect management of state administration.
